objdescid.origination: William Blakeinventor, delineator, etcher, engraver, printer

objinfo.framelines: There are slight suggestions of a framing line, contiguous with the edge of the design, along the left margin.
objinfo.binding: Pasted to a stub and bound as a frontispiece to *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* Copy B, the book bound from at least 1834 in half red morocco over marbled boards.The print was removed from the binding in 1977-78, trimmed slightly along its left margin (thereby eliminating any stab holes), pasted to a stub along its left margin, and rebound in the prior binding as the frontispiece facing the title page in the illuminated book.
objinfo.stabholes: none presently visibleBentley page 287 note 3 reports that the leaf is "stabbed in the same pattern as the other leaves" of *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* Copy B. These stab holes are recorded by Bentley page 298 as three holes, 7.7 cm. from the top and 3.2 cm. and 4.0 cm. apart. These holes are no longer present—see the comments on binding.

provenance.name: Bodleian Library
provenance.note: Francis Douce, possibly acquired with *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* Copy B in 1821 from "Dyer," probably either the London print dealer Charles George Dyer or the Exeter book dealer Gilbert Dyer; bound by 1834 as the frontispiece to *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* Copy B; bequeathed by Douce to the Bodleian Library, Oxford, in 1834.

desc.objtitle:
The Accusers of Theft Adultery Murder,
object 1 (Essick VIII)

objnote.p: This impression is in the first state of three. The identification of the figures as "The Accusers of Theft Adultery Murder" and "The Accuser The Judge & The Executioner" in the third-state inscriptions may not pertain to this first state. The verso of this impression is inscribed "3" in pencil and "Douce / MM. 834." in pen and ink. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three male figures stand in a line with bodies turned to face right. The rightmost figure is nude with prominent genitals. He has short curly hair and turns his head to look to the left. His eyes are wide and his mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of fear. Both arms are bent and crossed in front of his chest. With his right hand, he holds the haft of a sword, which is pointed upward. His legs are together with the right leg slightly in front of the left. To his left, the middle figure turns his head to look forward. He has long hair, a mustache, and a beard; he also wears a spiky crown. He may be a king. His eyes are wide and his mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of fear. His teeth are visible. He raises both bent arms upward and clutches his head with both hands. The fingers of both hands appear to be curled inward. This figure wears a cape or cloak that extends behind his thighs. He may also wear a sleeved shirt or breastplate. His legs are together with the right leg slightly in front of the left. The leftmost figure stands with his body facing right and head turned to look left. He has short wavy hair that stands on end and a large mustache; he may also have a beard. He wears a shirt composed of small circles, which may indicate chain mail, and pleated breeches or skirt(?). His costume suggests that of a Roman soldier. His right arm appears to be raised and extended behind the figure to his right. He may hold the spear visible above the middle figure's head. Only the right leg and foot of the leftmost figure are visible. The three figures stand between two wooden vertical objects, which may a door frame, as there appears to be a small horizontal step behind the figures' feet. The ground on which they stand may also be made of wood. Above their heads in the background is a sky with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Three male figures stand in a line with bodies turned to face right. The rightmost figure is nude with prominent genitals. He has short curly hair and turns his head to look to the left. His eyes are wide and his mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of fear. Both arms are bent and crossed in front of his chest. With his right hand, he holds the haft of a sword, which is pointed upward. His left hand appears to be in a fist. His legs are together with the right leg slightly in front of the left. Lines under his feet hint at sandals, but no straps are pictured.
The rightmost male figure holds the haft of a sword, which is pointed upward, in his right hand.

Three male figures stand in a line with bodies turned to face right. The middle figure turns his head to look forward. He has long hair, a mustache, and a beard; he also wears a spiky crown. He may be a king. His eyes are wide and his mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of fear. His teeth are visible. He raises both bent arms upward and clutches his head with both hands. The fingers of both hands appear to be curled inward. This figure wears a cape or cloak that extends behind his thighs. He may also wear a sleeved shirt or breastplate. His legs are together with the right leg slightly in front of the left. Lines under his feet hint at sandals, but no straps are pictured.

Three male figures stand in a line with bodies turned to face right. The leftmost figure stands with his body facing right and head turned to look left. He has short wavy hair that stands on end and a large mustache; he may also have a beard. He wears a shirt composed of small circles, which may indicate chain mail, and pleated breeches or skirt(?). His costume suggests that of a Roman soldier. His right arm appears to be raised and extended behind the figure to his right. He may hold the spear visible above the middle figure's head. Only the right leg and foot of the leftmost figure are visible. Lines under his foot hint at a sandal, but no straps are pictured.
The leftmost figure may hold the spear visible above the middle figure's head.

The three figures stand between two wooden vertical objects, which may be a door frame, as there appears to be a small horizontal step behind the figures' feet. The ground on which they stand may also be made of wood.
In the background, a sky with clouds in visible above the figures' heads.

l.note: The poorly formed colon following "5" might be random dots rather than purposeful punctuation.
